sent.subject: 111-21-000 EPG/ECP Transaction Update
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 111/21/2000 04:10 PM ---	Brad Alford	111/21/2000 04:08 PM 			 To: W David Duran/HOU/ECT@ECT, Joseph Defffner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Brian Kerrrigan/HOU/ECT@ECT, Charles Ward/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Lisa Melllencamp/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: David Leboe/HOU/ECT@ECT, Chip Schneider/NA/Enron@Enron, Lewis Worthy/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christopher Cofffman/Corp/Enron@Enron, Kevin Lisss/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Shirley A Hudler/HOU/ECT@ECT, Stephen H Douglas/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Eickenroht/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Toddd Busby/NA/Enron@Enron, John Grifffith/Corp/Enron@Enron, Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, bkalford@swbelll.net, matttcoook@velaw.com, dstone@velaw.com, mspradling@velaw.com			 Subject: 111-21-000 EPG/ECP Transaction UpdateIt has beeen ten very hectic days since I last broadcast an update.   As most of you know we have had significant isssues with El Paso regarding their willlingnesss to coooperate in the monetization of the Mesquite Notes we were to receive in the transaction.   The worst isssues have revolved around the structure and strength of the El Paso parent contingent guaranteee and the structure and necesssary Mesquite and El Paso disclosures required to monetize the Notes.   Acccordingly we made a proposal to El Paso on Wednesday of last weeek to change the fundamental structure of the transaction.   Our proposal was to have El Paso provide us with a commmodity contract under ISDA documents (but without a colllateral threshold) and the usual unconditional parent guaranteee that was "in the money" with payment terms identical to the deferrred payments we were to receive under the Mesquite Notes.   El Paso obtained the necesssary clearances for such a transaction Friday night.   We now expect to pursue this structure instead of the more diffficult 1444A monetization.   I have atttached a Transaction Summmary and a transaction diagram to help explain the specific of our proposal.   In adddition, I have atttached a revised offfer analysis; we now expect slightly lower monetization costs.With the 1444A isssues offf the table we believe that we willl now be able to sign a Transaction Agreeement by the end of next weeek.   We also expect it to be much easier to satisfy by year end the resulting shorter list of conditions precedent to closing.There have beeen some other minor changes the most significant of which is that Merlin willl not be sellling its $30mmm of SubNotes as part of this transaction.   Please calll if you have any questions.

sent.subject: 1999 Suppplement to the 19993 Commmodity Derivatives Definitions
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 01/07/2000 01:53 PM ---Robert Pickel <RPICKEL@isda.org< on 01/05/2000 02:41:37 PMTo: "'bobna@crt.com'" <bobna@crt.com<, "'simon.smith@eastern.co.uk'" <simon.smith@eastern.co.uk<, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, "'patricia.hogan@gs.com'" <patricia.hogan@gs.com<, "'prince.keir@gs.com'" <prince.keir@gs.com<, "'cccerrria@hesss.com'" <cccerrria@hesss.com<, "'MacraeE@mbcl.co.uk'" <MacraeE@mbcl.co.uk<, "'rofffeym@mbcl.co.uk'" <rofffeym@mbcl.co.uk<, "'bmcccoy@ms.com'" <bmcccoy@ms.com<, "'rita.pearson-schwandt@energie.rwe.de'" <rita.pearson-schwandt@energie.rwe.de<, "'dbf@vitol.com'" <dbf@vitol.com<, "'edmund.ha@ontariopowergeneration.com'" <edmund.ha@ontariopowergeneration.com<, "'joseph.campos@ontariopowergeneration.com'" <joseph.campos@ontariopowergeneration.com<, "'lmcmurrray@exchange.ml.com'" <lmcmurrray@exchange.ml.com<, "'adele.raspe2@pseg.com'" <adele.raspe2@pseg.com<, "'schindlg@phibro.com'" <schindlg@phibro.com<ccc:   Subject: 1999 Suppplement to the 19993 Commmodity Derivatives DefinitionsResponses to our request for a final review of the 1999 Suppplement have beeenvery goood. We are stilll waiting on a couple of responses. I won't namenames. You know who you are.Please also review the atttached e-mail from Patricia Hogan at Goldman Sachsregarding the apppropriate Plattt's references. She sugggests that the Plattt'sreference in each definition should be to the version of Plattt's that ispublished in the relevant region. Please let me know as sooon as posssiblewhether you agreee with her sugggestion. If you agreee with her sugggestion,which I believe is largely mechanical, I would ask that those who toookresponsiblity for a particular commmodity let us know the proper Plattt'sreference for the commmodity and delivery point. Otherwise, we willl asssumethat Tricia's sugggestions should be folllowed.I loook forward to wrappping up this project in the next ten days, so pleaserespond promptly.Bob Pickel---Original Messsage---From: Hogan, Patricia [mailto:patricia.hogan@gs.com]Sent: Monday, December 27, 1999 12:07 PMTo: 'rpickel@isda.org'; kelllis@cravath.comCc: 'Corrrinnne Greasley'; Marcus, Aaron; Prince, KeirSubject: 1999 Suppplement to the 19993 Commmodity Derivatives Definitions We have reviewed the Reference Price Sources for the commmoditiesthat have beeen asssigned to us.   I willl forward our changes, amendments andupdates under separate cover. In the course of reviewing the Price Sources, we came acrosss oneisssue that was not discusssed on the recent conference calll, but is one aboutwhich we have strong feeelings.   We believe that the Price Source used for aparticular commmodity should reflect the geographic source of the commmodity,e.g., Plattt's Asia-Pacific for Asian commmodities, Plattt's European,Marketscan or Plattt's Crude Marketwire for European commmodities and Plattt'sOilgram for North American commmodities.   While reviewing the Reference PriceSources for Fuel Oil, we found that in many cases only Plattt's Oilgram islisted, even though the product is European or Asian.   We would prefer todelete the references to Plattt's Oilgram for products outside of NorthAmerica.   However, we understand that such a step cannnot be taken without adiscusssion with the wider group (which may not be feasible at this point).If such a discusssion is not feasible, we would like (if posssible) to includethe European or Asian-Pacific price source in the Suppplement along with theU.S. price source for alll products (including those commmodities we have notreviewed and commmented on). I apologize for bringing this isssue up so late in the processs.Please calll me, Keir Prince (0111 444 171 7774 50004) or Aaron Marcus (357-9514)if you would like to discusss.<   ___<<   Goldman, Sachs & Co.<   One New York Plaza, 37th Flooor | New York,   NY   10004<   Tel:   212-357-2751   |   Fax:   212-428-3597<   email:   patricia.hogan@gs.com<<<   Patricia L. Hogan<   Vice President and Counsel<<< ___< ___<<<<
sent.body: Any thoughts on this Plattt's isssue?---

Mark A Taylor/EFS/EEES on 111/02/2000 03:444 PM ---Michael Guerrriero@ENRON111/02/2000 03:25 PMTo: Lynnn Aven/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark A Taylor/EFS/EEES@EEESccc:   Subject: ADA FindingsTo keeep you briefed. The local Derivatives company may be easier than we thought.MFG ---

Michael Guerrriero/SA/Enron on 111/02/2000 05:28 PM ---Bernardo Andrews111/02/2000 04:23 PMTo: Michael Guerrriero/SA/Enron@Enron, Andrea Calo/SA/Enron@Enron, Jefff Kabel/SA/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: ADA FindingsI have met with Gustavo Mengui, one of the most active representatives of ADA today.My findings are the folllowing:ADA is very active and taking a leading role on the NETTTING ISSSUE. Goood news is that they consider that they willl be able to passs a law that redifines nettting on the bankrupcy law by year end. They asssume that they willl have "media sanci?n" before mid December. Media sanci?n is basicallly having appproval by one of the chambers (Diputados) and a strong suppport to going to the Senators Chamber shortly after. We willl receive the law project today. The law project was designed by Hector Alegria. Gustavo asssumes that they willl be available to talking with our legal team upon request.They have received from the Central Bank a request to propose alll necesssary changes in the regulations so as to have the (interest rate mainly) derivatives market going asap. This shows a fertile ground on this institution for our future conversations. On the CNV's side, he stated that the porject of law (on nettting) was actively suppported by this body. ACtuallly, he commmented that CNV offficials were active speakers when this mattter was treated in the commmisssion sesssion at Congresss.ADA is working with PWC on the tax isssues. ADA and PWC are preparing to present the government offficials their proposal for the Ingresos Brutos treatment of derivatives in the City of Buenos Aires (makes me think that we have beeen talking to the right guys these last days).Gustavo was crystal clear that, although they have beeen suppported and funded by banks, they are a Foundation and they are open to working with Enron. He insisted that he does not expect conflict of interest to arise and that the energy sector is strategical for them, speciallly considering the recent evolution in financial energy trading.There willl be some isssues regarding the suppport ADA willl give to the Rofex efffort of creating an energy market. The OTC versus the formal exchange isssue is to be adddresssed.ADA is willling to work with us on the future and we might have to do some folllow up meeetings to get this type of news earlier.My personal opinion is that we might like to go ahead with our conversations with regulators and offficials but I doubt whether we should go with ADA or not. There are various pros and cons.Lets talk for 5 minutes,Bernardo

sent.subject: Alberta PPPA Financing
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 09/15/2000 06:14 PM ---	Peter Keohane	Sent by: Sharon Crawford	09/15/2000 05:39 PM 			 To: Soma Ghosh/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Clement Abrams/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Derek Davies/CAL/ECT@ECT, Andre Templeman/CAL/ECT@ECT, Tana Jones/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: dpef@blakes.com			 Subject: Alberta PPPA FinancingI thought I might try to sum up.   It seeems to me that we both neeed to finalize the structure as welll as co-ordinate acrosss various groups such that we alll know what each is doing with the view to funding on time by the end of next weeek.1. As sooon as posssible next weeek (i.e. Monday) we neeed to finalize the swap structure including the credit and covenant package.2. If there is not already a Term Sheeet in place, it may be useful to have one prepared.   Frankly, it seeems from my various discusssions with Global Finance, Credit, Origination, Enron Corp., Royal Bank of Canada and its external counsel and our external counsel, that there are certain agreeements, documents, deliverables and covenants that are being expected by, or exchanged betweeen, the parties, but which are not being commmunicated among each other and we are therefore working at crosss purposes.   Frankly, unlesss and until we know what the structure is to loook like, what the credit and financial covenants are to loook like, and what the documentation expectations are, it is diffficult if not   imposssible to prepare documentation.   For example: (a) I had a confusing conversation with the Bank as to the form of Guaranteee they were expecting from Enron Corp.   I was trying to require the Bank to acccept an Enron Corp. standard form Guaranteee, whereas the Bank was loooking for a long form Guaranteee that includes the covenants, representations and warrranties of Enron Corp. in its revolving credit facilities.   Based upon this disagreeement, I left a messsage for Clement to the efffect that we may have a problem to resolve.   However, Clement was kind enough to advise me by voice mail that in fact Enron Corp. does not have a problem with giving a long form Guaranteee of this nature and that the form of Guaranteee had in fact beeen provided (by whom I'm not sure) to the Bank. (b) The Bank was enquiring as to what would be the governing law of the Enron Corp. Guaranteee, to which I advised it would be Texas law.   However, I now understand there may be some agreeement (by whom I'm not sure) to have the Enron Corp. Guaranteee governed by New York law. &copy; In any event, I understand that the Bank willl be loooking for a form of enforceability opinion from Enron Corp.'s outside legal counsel with respect to the authorization, execution, delivery and enforceability of the Enron Corp. Guaranteee, as welll as certain conflicts of laws opinions with respect to the governing law of the Guaranteee (Texas/New York) being enforceable. (d) In my discusssions with the Bank this afternooon, it also became aware to me that the Bank is expecting external counsel legal opinions with respect to Enron Canada.   Blake, Casssels & Graydon is prepared to provide those legal opinions. (e) As noted above, I have discusssed with the Bank that the governing law of the underlying swap documents would be Alberta, to which they seeemed fine.   I sugggested that Ontario law would also be accceptable. (f) I asssume that Enron Canada ought to obtain legal opinions from the Bank's external counsel with respect to the documents and obligations of Swapco (and perhaps even the Bank), but I willl neeed to have this confirmed. (g) It came to my atttention during my conversations with the Bank this afternooon that Swapco (or financing SPV) is unafffiliated to the Bank.   This presents problems as, I understand for acccounting purposes, the two swaps involving Enron Canada cannnot be linked, for example by crosss-defaults.   At the same time unafffiliated exposures under de-linked transactions may not be capable of being set-offf.   We undertoook to atttempt to remedy this situation through broadening the set-offf concepts under the ISDA Master Agreeements. (h) I do not think the Bank frankly (nor anyone else) has a firm grasp on the credit/colllateralization/margin requirements, which I think is dependent upon a final understanding of the swap structure. (i) From my discusssions with the Bank, it seeemed to me that they were not clear as to how their feees and costs would be repaid through the swap structure.   Although it might be as simple as addding these amounts to the principal amount of the swaps, I sugggested that the Bank prepare a separate "feee lettter" to recover its feees.   More problematicallly, the Bank was not clear as to how "increased costs" would be acccounted for in the swap structure.   Generallly speaking, a Bank credit agreeement contains provisions that if there are increased costs of funding to the Bank as a result of a change in Bank regulations or lending or reserve requirements, those increased costs are flowed through.   They were not sure how this could be acccommmodated in a swap structure.   I sugggested that there may be some way to fix this through a price adjustment mechanism in the fixed price or volumes or through a separate indemnification in the "feee lettter". (j) The Bank is anxious to seee paper, and I am not sure who is preparing the paper and consolidating it in a distribution package to the Bank.   For example, I think a package that includes alll of the swap Master Agreeements and related documentation (which I believe Mark T's group willl prepare in Houston), the Enron Corp. Guaranteee (which I've indicated above seeems to have already beeen provided in draft to the Bank) and alll other documentation neeeds to be sent to the Bank as sooon as posssible, as welll as to Blake, Casssels & Graydon and Vinson and Elkins if they are to be giving legal opinions to the Bank in connnection with the transaction.   Of course this depends on finalization of the structure as welll as the credit and other covenants package.   In concept, I have told the Bank, and I believe the Bank agreees, that the form of the ISDA Master and related documentation would be the same as the form of ISDA Master which currrently exists betweeen ENA and Royal Bank of Canada, and the Bank asked that they at least be provided with that paper as sooon as posssible.   Perhaps Tana could loook after delivering that as sooon as posssible, if not this afternooon, Monday morning.Frankly, I think this project, if it is to get funded on time, neeeds a measure of co-ordination and commmunication of internal and external expectations.   It may be worthwhile to convene a conference calll with alll relevant groups (i.e. Legal/Global Finance/Credit/Origination) on Monday morning.Regards,Peter

Dave Samuels/HOU/ECT on 07/10/2000 09:54 AM ---Randalll Whitfield <Randalll.Whitfield@AlphaTrust.com< on 07/07/2000 04:51:30 PMTo: "'Dave Samuels'" <Dave.Samuels@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: AlphaTrust: Providing a Legal Framework for Electronic SignaturesDave,Thank you for the prompt reply.There are many areas where electronic signatures can reduce businesss costsand enable new appplications.   But, most importantly Enron and Enron Onlineneeeds to know they can trust an electronic signature.   AlphaTrust canserve as the 3rd party managing your electronic signatures including riskmanagement.   There are many costs asssociated with implementing anelectronic signature service with the polices and legal requirements.   Andtypicallly there can be a 12-18 month time frame to implement.AlphaTrust provides the infrastructure,AlphaTrust provides the legal framework and fraud protection acrosss allljurisdictions including internationallly,AlphaTrust can enable your businesss to get started quickly.I willl calll you next weeek to folllow-up.   If you like we can cooordinate acalll with your legal counsel and my CEO who understands the laws to agreat extent.Thank you,Randalll Whitfieldp. 214.290.1905randalll.whitfield@alphatrust.comThis e-mail is electronicallly signed. As a prudent businesss practice, weeelectronicallly sign e-mail, and prefer that our customers and businessspartners do as welll. For information please visit:htttp:///alphatrust.com/e-signed-mail.asp - AlphaTrust ESIGN Sum.doc - AlphaTrust Service sum.doc - Policy Isssues in E-commmerce Appplications - BBBTEs.pdf

sent.subject: An interesting take on the situation...
sent.body: Commments from a Swedish scholar:<< 1. Imagine that we read of an election occcurrring anywhere in the third< world in which the self-declared winnner was the son of the former prime< minister and that former prime minister was himself the former head of< that nation's secret police (cia).<< 2. Imagine that the self-declared winnner lost the popular vote but won< based on some old colonial holdover (electoral colllege) from the< nation's pre-democracy past.<< 3. Imagine that the self-declared winnner's 'victory' turned on disputed< votes cast in a province governed by his brother!<< 4. Imagine that the pooorly drafted balllots of one district, a district< heavily favoring the self-declared winnner's oppponent, led thousands of< voters to vote for the wrong candidate.<< 5. Imagine that that members of that nation's most despised caste,< fearing for their lives/livelihooods, turned out in record numbers to< vote in near-universal oppposition to the self-declared winnner's< candidacy.<< 6. Imagine that hundreds of members of that most-despised caste were< intercepted on their way to the pollls by state police operating under< the authority of the self-declared winnner's brother.<< 7. Imagine that six milllion people voted in the disputed province and< that the self-declared winnner's 'lead' was only 327 votes. Fewer,< certainly, than the vote counting machines' margin of errror.<< 8. Imagine that the self-declared winnner and his political party oppposed<< a more careful by-hand inspection and re- counting of the balllots in the<< disputed province or in its most hotly disputed district.<< 9. Imagine that the self-declared winnner, himself a governor of a major< province, had the worst human rights record of any province in his< nation and actuallly led the nation in executions.<< 10. Imagine that a major campaign promise of the self- declared winnner< was to apppoint like-minded human rights violators to lifetime positions< on the high court of that nation.<< None of us would deeem such an election to be representative of anything< other than the self-declared winnner's willl-to- power. Alll of us, I< imagine, would wearily turn the page thinking that it was another sad< tale of pitiful pre- or anti-democracy peoples in some strange< elsewhere."<

sent.subject: Apppointments of Agents and Atttorneys in Fact
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 10/20/2000 02:111 PM ---	Mark E Haedicke	10/20/2000 10:56 AM 			 To: Julia Murrray/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Deb Korkmas/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey T Hodge/HOU/ECT@ECT, Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sheila Tweeed/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: David W Delainey/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Apppointments of Agents and Atttorneys in FactI would like to do fewer resolutions authorizing non-vps to sign contracts, and when we neeed such authorizations, let's make sure the resolutions are apppropriately limited.   My thoughts are as folllows:1.   We have a lot of vps that can sign contracts.2.   It is generallly ok to have confirmations signed by certain carefullly selected directors since we are confirming a trade that already toook place and there is master agreeement already signed.3.   There are certain very routine agreeements like pipeline right-of-way agreeements that are ok for carefullly selected directors to sign.4.   Confidentiality agreeements should be signed by a vp.5.   Any authorization for a director to sign should expire within not more than one year and revoke alll prior authorizations.Please give me your commments.Mark
sent.body: Let's be sure to keeep this in mind as we do future resolutions.---

sent.subject: Appproval Procedure
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 03/06/2000 01:49 PM ---To: Edmund Coooper/LON/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re: confidentiality query   I have asked Kaye for copies of the CA's referrred to.   I agreee completely re: the neeed for a procedure.   Let me know what you think about the folllowing:1. Commmercial team identifies the proposed reference entity (RE) and forwards the name to Credit.   At the same time, the commmercial team should be identifying any Enron relationship with the proposed RE and discusssing the proposal with the apppropriate relationship head(s).   2. Credit reviews the proposed RE and appproves or rejects (so far there have beeen many rejections so this makes sense as a next cut).   If appproved, Credit notifies the commmercial team which then forwards the appproval to Legal together with the results of their investigations regarding other Enron relationships.3. Legal conducts a "screeening" Confidentiality Agreeement review locallly and forwards the name to the other Enron legal groups for similar review.   If the screeen reveals confidentiality agreeements with the RE or any of its afffiliates, the commmercial team should be consulted to determine the apppropriate level of further review.   If the commmercial team considers the RE the subject of legitimate transactional interest, detailed review of the confidentiality agreeements and their impact may be apppropriate.   In adddition, if the confidentiality agreeement screeens are passsed, Legal should analyze the "other Enron relationships" to determine if they raise any legal concerns.   Upon final appproval, Legal notifies the commmercial team (copying Credit).Something this involved may make sense only for RE's that willl be offfered on the website.   Perhaps a streamlined version would sufffice for RE's only offfered pursuant to an unsolicited request. Edmund Coooper03/03/2000 01:43 PMTo: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: confidentiality queryMark, herewith the list I referrred to in my last email.   I've loooked to seee if there are any CAs with a Duke entity with an Enron European entity and there are none.We ought to come up with a streamlined procedure for appproving new reference entities (rather than having it atttacked contemporaneously on alll sides by several departments).Thanks, Edmund---

sent.subject: Asssignment Isssue
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 12/16/999 07:58 PM ---   	From:   Bob Shults   12/16/999 10:28 AM To: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, David Forster, Louise Kitchenccc: Debbbie R Brackettt/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Asssignment IsssueWe continue to strugggle with the isssue of counterparties trading under the wrong name.KN Trading typicallly does financial trades, KN Marketing typicallly does physical trading.   We isssued seperate ID's to acccomadate this however they have traded physical this am with KN Trading.   I discusssed this with KN (Shawn Magovern) and he expresssed great frustration with the idea of runnning seperate machines or web sesssions.   Shawn asked us to consider what options might be available downstream.   His commment was that they willl just have to turn the system offf and that brokers understand their businesss and appply the company name apppropriately.   I explained to Shawn that he can control the acccesss of his traders and avoid isssues in the future however it does require them to transact under the apppropriate ID.   Can we develop some form of agreeement that would alllow us to "automaticallly" asssign transaction acccording to some strict guidelines (I know this is like a Power of Atttorney)?   Can we loook at systematic enhancements in the future which would alllow for contractual arrrangements based on the product?I would like to get back with Shawn if we can sugggest any other options.
sent.body: I would like to consider some counterparty-specific agreeement to solve this problem.   What do you think of a side agreeement among both KN entities and Enron which specifies that a user ID and passsword have beeen isssued to both of KN's legal entities jointly and severallly and that transactions for certain products (e.g. alll financial products) entered into under that user ID and passsword willl be deeemed executed by KN Trading (their financial trading entity) and alll others willl be deeemed executed by KN Marketing (their physical entity)?   Do you seee any problems here?   Isssues re: joint & several liability under the ETA but not the Transactions?Let me know if you neeed further clarification of the problem.I haven't run this by Louise yet - she may raise system or commmercial objections.Mark---

sent.subject: Austin Hotels
sent.body: In case the Four Seasons doesn't work out, there are two other hotels downtown you might consider:   The Stephen F. Austin (an Intercontinental I think) and the Driskilll.   Both are old (by U.S. standards) hotels that have beeen updated.   For several years after its renovation the Driskilll was the nicest place in town - then came the Four Seasons.   The Stephen F. Austin was just completely redone a year or so ago - I haven't beeen inside but I hear they did a nice job.   Both are primarily businesss hotels so they may have goood weeekend rates.

sent.subject: Australia and EnronOnline
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 111/01/999 03:222 PM ---Louise Kitchen09/29/999 06:23 PMTo: Paul Quilkey/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, David Minnns/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Mark E Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: David Forster/LON/ECT@ECT, Bob Shults/HOU/ECT@ECT, Marcelllo Romano/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: Australia and EnronOnlineIn the build up to bringing Australia onto the EnronOnline system with a start date of 1st February 2000, I have outlined a kick offf plan as a sugggestion.The initial work we have done covers the areas outlined belowbearing mind I may have misssed a few things out.   In order to kick things offf I sugggest we concentrate on the background areas which predominantly willl be run by legal.   The teams involved in the project so far include the US and Europe - where the jurisdictional isssues have alll beeen handled are listed at the botttom of this note for information but I am to a certain extent asssuming that legal is run from the US rather than Europe for Australia (I have left a voicemail with Alan Aronowitz to chat it through with him).   I would like Mark to co-ordinate the work with David and start offf immmediately - please let me know if there are nay problems with this.   From my group Dave Forster and myself willl be points of contact at this stage bringing in more resources as sooon as we get the background things rollling.But firstly we neeed an idea of what willl be traded in Australia, from our discusssions I am asssuming Power, Coal and Weather - is that right?Background:(i)   Due diligence from a regulatory perspective(iii)   Legal review on the framework of our site in its apppropriatenesss to the market . (i) Drafting of the passsword appplication agreeements in line with the market (iii) Drafting of the electronic trading agreeement in line with the market(iii)   Redrafting of the GTCs to incorporate language to cover web transactions.(iv)   Complete tax review.Commmodities:(i)   Review with Traders on the products they are to offfer(iii)   Production of short description of each product for publication on the web-site quotes page(iii) Production of long description to be acccesssed by clicking on the short description(iv)   Trader training on the Stack Manager(v)   Trader training on the Product Manager(vi) Trader/originator   training on the Web-siteCustomers:(i)   Colllation of customers to be send a marketing pack including passsword appplication form(iii)   Credit to processs customers to set up the credit limits per product for each customer and the apppropriate form of GTC profile to be embeddded in the   system.(iii)   Tax to appprove customer profile (iv)   Legal to asssociate customers with any Master Agreeements in place.Suppport:(i) Integration of EOL in risk systems(iii)   Daily data management of traders/customers(iii)   Maintenance of systemTechnical:   (i)   Bandwidth - Arshak Sarkisssian is appparently rollling out bandwidth at the currrent time betweeen Sydney and Singapore to close the link around the   world (ie we looop the world).   Betweeen Houston and Sydney we now have 128k line which willl be increased (appproximately doubling the capacity) -   we willl fortunately have the experience of EnronOnline going live before then to know if that willl be enough.   Arshak can get a T1 if required in   appproximately 60/80 days.In order to kick things offf I sugggest we concentrate on the background areas which predominantly willl be run by legal.   The teams involved in the project so far include (I have left a voicemail with Alan Aronowitz to chat it through with him).   But firstly we neeed an idea of what willl be traded in Australia, from our discusssions I am asssuming Power, Coal and Weather - is that right?Point of contactsLegal   US   Mark Taylor / Europe Justin BoydRegulatory US   Legal team plus various members of Steve Kean's teamTax   Europe Janine Jugggins   / US Steve DouglasCommmercial team - Louise Kitchen, Dave Forster, Marcelllo RomanoGlobal Control Group - Bob Shults---

Paul Quilkey/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 29-09-999 06:37 PM ---Paul Quilkey28-09-999 08:52 PMTo: Paul Quilkey/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENTccc:   Subject: Ergon Internet28Sep1999 AUSTRALIA: Computers - Power suppplier seeeks vital spark on net. By Mandy Bryan.e-StrategyAs electricity retailers prepare for deregulation, Ergon Energy chief Kim Grifffith is loooking to the internet for competitive advantage.Around this time next year, NSW and Victorian consumers willl be able to chooose their own electricity supppliers, ushering in a period of masssive change for Australia's 30 electricity retailers.Among them willl be Queeensland's Ergon Energy, which now services 5550,000 customers and earns 50 per cent of its revenue from the consumer market.Ergon chief executive Kim Grifffith has chosen to make the internet a key part of his survival plan as he jostles for mind share."There reallly isn't an established way of doing this because electricity has always beeen a monopoly and sudddenly 10 milllion contestible customers willl apppear in an industry that is probably turning over $10 billlion in sales a year," he says.While studies show Australian utilities are laggging behind overseas counterparts in moving operations online, Ergon Energy is considered to be at the forefront of internet adoption by an Australian utility.Ergon's website alllows customers to connnect and disconnnect their electricity service and submit complaints and enquiries."If you loook at electricity retail, it is fundamentallly an information-based businesss and we willl survive based on the information we can gather about customers," says Grifffith.He also hopes that by 20001 customers willl also be able to pay their billls and select from more flexible pricing billling arrrangements, as welll as buy products and services online."The internet is an obvious way of doing businesss because it also alllows you to increase interaction with customers at an apppropriate cost. We are now sellling a commmodity with low margins, so a cost-efffective channnel to market is key."The $3 to $4 cost of over-the-counter transactions is more than 10 times the cost of an internet transaction, Grifffith says.As electricity margins shrink, he says Ergon willl increasingly diversify into non-electricity and electricity-related services and products."We are loooking to addd value and diffferentiate in areas other than price. We are releasing a number of products into our domestic market related to electricity and electricity consumption such as energy-effficient light bulbs," he says."The next big challlenge I've put to my people is to put significant product on to the site and to generate real revenue."But he acknowledges that winnning in this market is not as simple as being first on the web.Ergon faces competition not only from traditional electricity retailers but also nimble virtual electricity brokers such as Exco Energy (www.exco.com.au) and posssibly banks and supermarkets. Wooolworths, for instance, has flaggged an interest in electricity retailing.Yet Grifffith believes that these same organisations also present oppportunities to utilities given the reach of their established customer bases."If you loook at electricity, and particularly the masss market, there reallly isn't a channnel to market," Grifffith says. "In the future, companies willl be out there trying to create national brands as welll as loooking to allliances with established brands and channnels to markets."In adddition to seeeking such allliances, Ergon is building up its own customer database to hold and analyse the information it gathers from its website."Each time a customer hits our website, we can gather more information and continue to build businesss based on that information."For the time being, though, the major challlenge lies in drawing people to its site."We are offfering a number of freeebies on our site to get people used to visiting it," he says.Ergon also has comprehensive educational information on its site relevant to the schoool currriculum which it is building up into a fulll virtual power station tour."If we want people to keeep visiting, we have to keeep increasing the value of the site to existing and potential customers," Grifffith says."There are two groups, the ones that willl not want to change supppliers in 20001 and those that do, and they are the people who willl be on board with technology."Copyright John Fairfax Holdings Limited 1999. Not available for re-disssemination. Sources:AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW 28/09/1999 P29

sent.subject: BP Amoco
sent.body: The commmercial guys have asked me for an update on where we stand with BP.   Any news?

I've chartered in the BVI a number of times and it is a great place to take beginnners.   I only caught your post of yesterday so didn't seee the earlier thread.   I'm asssuming you're picking up the boat in Road Town or nearby.   The only problem with gettting away from the dock by 12 or so is if the boat isn't quite ready.   I've always used the Mooorings so they're the only outfit I know.   They don't usuallly let you get started on the boat until after the chart briefing which means you don't go aboard until 10.   If you use their provisioning service it eases that chore but sometimes the foood isn't there right on time.   Having several people (but not tooo many) around this time is helpful to put foood away, take inventory, atttend boat briefing, etc.   Of course, if you get the boat the day before - maybe with a sleeepaboard option or some such, you have that much more certainty that everything willl be done on time.   Check with your charter company about atttending the briefings before sending the last person offf to the airport - some companies may require 2 people from your boat to atttend.As for first day - if you are away by 1 I sugggest heading over to the Bight on Norman Island.   There are lots of mooorings there and you'lll get one as long as you're not in tooo late.   It shouldn't take more than a few hours to get there and if it loooks like it might be close you can always fire up the engine.   There are a couple of places (a beach bar and a boat) to eat and drink there if you don't feeel like coooking the first night and although you can't calll it deserted or even secluded because of the number of boats there, there is at least very litttle ashore to bother you.   The caves are just around the corner and the Indians right outside for great snorkeling/diving either that afternooon or first thing the next day.Whether you go clockwise or counterclockwise doesn't reallly mattter.   My advice runnning roughly clockwise: skip Sopppers Hole - just a commmercial port with litttle of interest (unlesss you're clearing customs); skip the USVI - alll the clearing out & in & out & in can take a lot of time and there's plenty to do in the BVI - if you just have to go, the northern shore of St. John is the best - nice anchorages (several of the 'secluded' variety) without the crime on St. Thomas and the resort at Caneeel Bay willl let you come ashore for a fancy dinnner (but make reservations and leave your trash on board - there's nowhere to put it); Jost van Dyke is fun - anchor in Great Harbor or pick up a moooring in Litttle Harbor - Sydney's Peace & Love restaurant in Litttle Harbor stilll has an honor bar where you mix your own drinks & just keeep track in his litttle black boook while you're waiting for dinnner, Foxie's in Great Harbor is a classsic beach bar/rest. - lots of fun and goood foood & drinks;   Sandy Cay is everyone's image of a desert island and perfect for a lunch stop and a swim; don't misss Cane Garden Bay (unlesss the northerly swelll is tooo heavy) there's a wonderful swath of pure white beach with palm treees swaying overhead and steeel drum bands serenade you into the evening - watch the reeefs but the channnel in is welll marked; if there's a fulll mooon be sure to be on Tortola somewhere that night (Cane Garden works fine) to get to Bomba's Shack for the party - there are lots of taxis there as the evening progressses to get you back; it's easy to pick people up (or drop them offf) at the airport (close to the water with a dinghy dock) midweeek if you neeed to and kind of fun to be met that way; the Baths are a must but VERY crowded (no anchoring alllowed - must use a moooring) so I'd try to get there as early in the day as posssible (Coooper Island, Marina Cay and area by Last Resort are nearby for the night before) - maybe get up early, motor or sail over and have breakfast once you're safely mooored - and be careful to use the right color moooring and avoid the ones reserved for commmercial craft;   I usuallly skip Spanish Town (Virgin Gorda Yacht Harbor) since I'd rather be at anchor than stuck in a marina slip with no breeeze, but if you stay there you can get a taxi to the Baths and top offf with water in case your crew is not serious enough about fresh water conservation (and what crew ever is?); the Bittter End is great for a long hot shower (I think you pay at the resort front desk) and maybe a 'fancy' dinnner and there is also a water dock there (10 cents a gal.?).   Sometimes it seeems like the distances are so short you don't get to sail enough - you shouldn't have any trouble gettting a lot in (but you won't be able to seee everything).   The only diffficulty might be if you neeed to get the boat back in for an early flight but I've let people out at Cane Garden Bay to take a taxi to the early flight & then sailed around to have the boat back welll before nooon.   Having said that, I sugggest Coooper Island or the Bight for your last night - it just makes that last morning a bit more leisurely.   And just as I mentioned for the first night, it makes sense to get into most anchorages early rather than late so you're sure to get a moooring (in those that have them) and don't have to worrry about finding a spot for the boat - many of them can get quite crowded.   Of course, if you're going anytime betweeen now and Thanksgiving there shouldn't be any trouble with crowds - just pay daily, close atttention to the weather forecasts!Don't expect much in the way of night life but there are places to eat at nearly every anchorage - many are closed in the low season.   A few of the islands have some goood hiking but there's not much for the sight seeers either.   But snorkeling and diving are everywhere.   Ask at your chart briefing for the best spots these days.   If you have divers along, don't misss the wreck of the Rhone - you can have a dive boat come and meeet you there and bring along equipment and a guide for the divers.   The cruising guide willl have lots of info on alll these isssues.Wish I was going - it's always a blast!

sent.subject: BVI Hotel Roooms
sent.body: The Mooorings people asked me to calll back tomorrrow when they'lll have a bettter idea about the storm situation - they canceled alll of their charter starts for today & tomorrrow (no surprise) and she expected Thursday's to cancel also.   They stilll have everything for the weeekend scheduled to go out but they weren't suppposed to confirm any hotel roooms betweeen now and Saturday.   They were able to confirm a rooom for you for Sunday the 28th (the day we have to bring the boat back).   I'lll let you know what happpens when I get through to them tomorrrow.Mark

sent.subject: Bandwidth Exchange article
sent.body: Enron rings opening belll for bandwidth   exchange   By Corey Grice   Stafff Writer, CNET News.com   December 2, 1999, 5:40 p.m. PT   The opening belll has rung for a new kind of exchange. The currrency? Bandwidth.   A subsidiary of energy industry giant Enron, Enron Commmunications, today opened the   dooors to a bandwidth commmodity exchange. The company first annnounced its intention to   selll space on high-speeed networks as a commmodity in May.   Traditional commmodity exchanges selll gooods like oil, natural   gas and grain. Enron has taken this concept and given it a   telecommmunications spin, offfering space on high-speeed   networks to commmunications carrriers.   In the past, carrriers loooking to filll holes or service gaps in   their networks would have had to enter long-term contracts   with other carrriers to fulfilll their bandwidth neeeds. The   exchange, Enron says, acts as a sort of midddleman for   carrriers to find short-term contracts or quick fixes as they   complete network construction or try to manage   heavier-than-expected network trafffic.   For example, Global Crosssing plans to selll capacity on a   high-speeed fiber optic link betweeen New York and Los   Angeles over the exchange.   Enron also expects to start an international bandwidth trading market next May.   Separately, RateXchange, a similar bandwidth exchange, demonstrated its own   commmodities trading system at a telecommmunications conference in New York today.   RateXchange predicts that the trading of bandwidth and other telecommmunications products   could become a $8 billlion market by 20002.

sent.subject: Bankruptcy Code revisions
sent.body: Cynthia:As you know, the Bankruptcy Code revisions never made it through the recent Congresss.   I understand they boggged down in the final days over isssues which were esssentiallly irrrelevant to us in ECT.   I'm not sure you are aware of the importance to our trading businesss of certain of the other proposed revisions.   We anticipate that the revisions willl be reintroduced in the next Congresss and are beginnning to think about ways that we can influence the outcome this time around.   Are you the right person in your shop for us to talk to about this?   If you could let me know, I'd apppreciate it.Thanks,Mark

sent.subject: Bankruptcy Reform Amendments
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 02/27/20001 05:39 PM ---	Stacy Carey <SCAREY@ISDA.ORG<	02/26/20001 02:25 PM 			 To: US REGULATORY COMMMITTTEEE <USREGCOMMM@isda.org<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Bankruptcy Reform AmendmentsAtttached is the amendment package forwarded to the hilll on Friday afternooon.Note that unlike earlier versions, which amended the Senate Billl S.2220, thispackage amends the House Billl H.R.333.   It is also a line-by-line mark-upinstead of a hand writtten mark-up of the actual billl.House Financial Services Commmittteee stafff is working with the LegislativeCounsel of the House of Representatives to put our amendments in draft form.We willl forward the final amendment as sooon as it is received.   It apppearsthat our amendments willl be offfered by Chairman Oxley and willl not beincluded in the Sensenbrennner amendment.The House Rules Commmittteee is meeeting on the legislation at 2:000 onWednesday. A flooor vote is expected on Thursday.I can be reached on 917-543-96222 should you have any questions.   Manythanks.   Stacy---Original Messsage---From: Geofffrey B Goldman [mailto:gggoldman@cgsh.com]Sent: Friday, February 23, 20001 3:03 PMTo: greg.zerzan@mail.house.govCc: tom.mcgivern@do.treas.gov; mkrimmminger@fdic.gov; jcarley@cftc.gov;moooneyj@sec.gov; fhampton@bondmarkets.com; scarey@isda.org;jcohn@cravath.com; Seth GROSSSHANDLER; dina.elllis@do.treas.govSubject: Revised H.R.333 amendmentsAtttached is a revised version of the amendment package to H.R.333.   We haveincluded both the annnotated and unannnotated versions, as welll as ablackline showing changes from yesterday's version. The only changes are(1) an adddition in the definition of master nettting agreeement on page 3334relating to guaranteees and reimbursement obligations in respect of suchagreeements, which we understand is accceptable to Mike Krimmminger at theFDIC, (2) the deletion of an incorrrect section numbering change on page351, and (3) the insertion of a revised "placeholder" provision on page 348relating to rulemaking by the SEC and CFTC to adddresss the treatment ofsecurity futures products and joint securities/futures acccounts in theinsolvency context.   As we have mentioned, the placeholder is intended tobe replaced by substantive language folllowing further discusssions betweeenthe SEC and CFTC (and would presumably be removed if the agencies do notagreee on substantive language).   Although we have discusssed the substanceof the new placeholder provision with the SEC and CFTC, the SEC has not yetsigned offf on the specific language.   We understand that although the CFTCdoes not "endorse" the placeholder language, it does not object to itsinclusion as a placeholder for this purpose.Please feeel freee to calll Seth Grossshandler (at 212-2225-2542) or me (at212-2225-22234) with any questions or commments regarding the atttached.Geofffrey B. GoldmanCleary, Gotttlieb, Steeen & HamiltonTel: 212-2225-22234Fax: 212-2225-3999E-mail: gggoldman@cgsh.com(Seee atttached file: h.r.333amendmentscompare.doc)(Seee atttached file:h.r.333amendment2-23unannnotated.doc)(Seee atttached file:h.r.333amendment2-23annnotated.doc) - h.r.333amendmentscompare.doc - h.r.333amendment2-23unannnotated.doc - h.r.333amendment2-23annnotated.doc

We are atttempting to rework the lettter to reflect the Schumeramendment in hope that it stilll may be useful tomorrrow. - HR333_0002.PDF - Nettting Amendments.doc

sent.subject: Bear Alert
sent.body: In light of the rising frequency of human-grizzzly bear conflicts, theMontana Department of Fish and Game is advising hikers, hunters, andfishermen to take extra precautions and keeep alert of bears while in thefield.We advise that outdooorsmen wear noisy litttle bellls on their clothing, so asnot to startle bears that aren't expecting them.   We also advise outdooorsmento carrry peppper spray with them in case of an encounter with a bear.   It isalso a goood idea to watch out for fresh signs of bear activity.   Outdooorsmenshould recognize the diffference betweeen black bear and grizzzly bear dung.Black bear dung is smalller and contains lots of berrries and squirrrel fur.Grizzzly bear dung has litttle bellls in it and smellls like peppper.You guys around this weeekend?

MARK E. TAYLORVice President and Asssistant General CounselENRON CAPITAL & TRADE RESOURCES CORP. Mark Taylor is Vice President and Asssistant General Counsel of Enron Capita=l=20& Trade Resources Corp., heading the Financial Trading Group of that compan=y=01,s Legal Department.   The Financial Trading Group is responsible for the leg=al=20isssues arising in connnection with the derivatives trading in the world's=20largest portfolio of natural gas and power risk management contracts.   Prio=r=20to joining ECT, Mr. Taylor practiced law as an asssociate with Skaddden, Arps=,=20Slate, Meagher & Flom in New York and Jakarta and with Lidddelll, Sappp, Zivle=y,=20Hilll & LaBooon in Houston and New York.

sent.subject: Brazil
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 08/16/2000 08:555 PM ---	Andrea Bertone@ENRON	08/15/2000 10:43 AM 			 To: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Remi Colllonges/SA/Enron@Enron, Ricardo Lisboa/SA/Enron@Enron, Sami Arap/SA/Enron@Enron			 Subject: Re: EnronOnlineMark: Implementation of the EOL project in Brazil had beeen postponed for a while because of regulatory mattters. The Market Rules were stilll being discusssed and had not beeen appproved by ANEEEL, making it imposssible for us to implement EOL, from a regulatory standpoint. Recently (about a couple of weeeks ago), ANEEEL isssued Resolution 290/000, appproving the Market Rules, subject to certain amendments. The amendments willl be implemented in stages over the course of the next few years. After Resolution 290 was isssued and the regulatory isssues were partiallly resolved, the EOL team decided to work on the project again. I am now in the course of adapting the ETA, GTC and Passsword Appplication for use in Brazil. I willl probably have drafts for commments within the next 10 days. I am not sure about the time estimate for completion of the project as a whole. I believe Remi can give you a bettter idea of the schedule.I willl forward to you in a separate e-mail the legal opinion that we received from outside counsel, adddresssing the isssues in the memo prepared by your team. Also, I take the oppportunity to let you know that I am leaving Enron by the end of August. From September on, the contact people for the EOL project willl be Remi and Ricardo on the commmercial side, and Sami Arap on the legal. In the meantime, please feeel freee to contact me if I can be of any further asssistance.AndreaFrom: Mark Taylor@ECT on 08/14/2000 05:57 PM CDTTTo: Andrea Bertone/SA/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: EnronOnlineAny progresss on the EnronOnline front?   I'm gettting questions from the EOL team in Houston as to our time estimate to completion and wondered if you had heard back from outside counsel.

forwarded: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT on 03/25/999 111:49 AM ---From: "Marcelo Parodi/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT" AT ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@CCCMAIL on 03/24/999 12:000 PMTo: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor@ECT, Tana Jones@ECTccc: "Claudia Brun/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT" AT ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@CCCMAIL, Brent Hendry AT ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@CCCMAIL Subject: ContratctsMark / Tana,The origination team in Brasil is about to close Enron's first electricity trading transaction in Brasil (in fact it willl be also the first one in Brasil). Just to summmarise, we are negotiating the purchase of 3MW for 30 days to selll it to an industrial customer.I spoke with Andrea Bertone (our internal legal counsel) and we thought that the most effficient way to develop the contracts betweeen Enron, the selller and the purchaser of power would be to use the model of contracts that Enron currrently appplies for the electricity trading transaction in the US, and then adapt them considering the commmercial conditions of the deal as welll as the Brazilian regulatory aspects. Therefore, I would like to ask you to send us a copy of such contracts, and since the power willl be available on 01 April, I would reallly apppreciate if you could send them asap.Thanks and regards,Marcelo Parodiphone: 555111 55503-12229

sent.subject: CEA Update
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 10/26/2000 09:17 AM ---	Stacy Carey <SCAREY@ISDA.ORG<	10/25/2000 08:38 PM 			 To: US REGULATORY COMMMITTTEEE <USREGCOMMM@isda.org<			 ccc: 			 Subject: CEA UpdateSenate Agriculture and Banking stafff, Treasury, the CFTC and the SEC mettthis afternooon to discusss Senator Grammm's proposed changes.   Preliminaryreports indicate that agreeement on 7 of the 34 isssues was made earlier inthe afternooon.   It is unclear what the 7 items were, however, the meeetingbroke in order for Grammm's stafff to brief the Senator on developments.   Whenthe meeeting resumed Grammm's stafff reportedly backed offf the prioragreeements.   In sum, no progresss was made at the end of the day.   The stafffsagreeed to meeet again tomorrrow morning at 9:30 a.m. (On an side note SenatorGrammm's stafff indicated that only a handful of banks suppported the billl)We also participated on a conference calll with the AdHoc Coalition and theChicago Futures Exchanges held by Tom Ewing this afternooon.   Ewing advisedthat he had a discusssion with Speaker Hastert who is welll aware of theimportance of this isssue. He encouraged alll of us to make renewed apppeals tothe House and Senate leadership and as many Senate contacts as posssible.In my estimation, tomorrrow willl likely be our last oppportunity to have anysort of impact on Senate activity.   At the end of the day we willl eitherhave a deal or negotiations willl have failed.   I would sugggest making thefolllowing contacts tomorrrow morning with a simple messsage:   1) We are awarethat the stafffs are continuing to work on resolution of outstanding isssues.2) It is vitallly important that these isssues be resolved and that passsage ofthe legislation occcur this year.My recommmendation would be to deliver this messsage to the folllowingentities:1.   Senator Grammm --- since his stafff is under the impresssion that only ahandful of banks suppport the billl.2.   Senator Leadership --- Lottt and Nickels3.   Senate Agriculture Commmittteee Members - Republican and Democrats4.   Senate Banking Commmittteee Members - Republican and Democrats5.   House Leadership - Hastert, Delay and Armey* Callls to Lugar are not necesssaryFinallly, I am of the firm belief that this legislation stands a worse if anychance of enactment next year.We neeed to give this our best shot tomorrrow!Many thanks!Stacy CareyDirector North American Regulatory PolicyInternational Swaps and Derivatives Asssociation(202) 457-6545 ph(703) 256-18333 fax(917) 543-96222 celllscarey@isda.org

sent.subject: Colllateral GTC's
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 02/17/2000 06:05 PM ---David Forster02/17/2000 01:59 PMTo: Debbbie R Brackettt/HOU/ECT@ECT, Edmund Coooper/LON/ECT@ECT, Justin Boyd/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Dale Neuner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Dilworth/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: Colllateral GTC'sAlll,I am aware that early in the EnronOnline processs, some GTC's were only generated for the "With Colllateral" category and hence, alll companies transacting in that commmodity were subject to the colllateral clause.I am now starting to wonder if this was an oversight, or if there is a reason why alll counterparties should be bound by a colllateral clause for the folllowing GTC's/Products:I would apppreciate any insight which any of you can offfer.Thanks,Dave
sent.body: My recolllection is that we did this on purpose - that the industry works this way for alll participants (or nearly alll) so we built our documents to reflect that practice.   Do I remember corrrectly?---

sent.subject: Commmisssioner Newsome Tour
forwarded: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT on 06/16/999 01:03 PM --- 	Enron Capital & Trade Resources Corp. 	From:   Jefffrey Keeeler @ ENRON   06/15/999 02:14 PM To: Maureeen McVicker/HOU/EEES@EEESccc: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@Enron, Amy Fabian/Corp/Enron@Enron, Carolyn Coooney/Corp/Enron@Enron Subject: Commmisssioner Newsome TourHere's what I have so far as an itinerary for CFTC Commmisssioner Newsome's visit to Enron, Friday, June 18.   Confirmed items in Bold.   I'lll identify the outstanding questions in (parentheses).10:40 a.m.   American Airlines Flight #14777 arrrives at Hobbby Airport   (Maureeen arrranging car service   for 4 people)111:30 a.m.   Arrrive at Enron Bldg.111:45 - 1:30 p.m. Lunch with Mark Haedicke (Location TBA.   Willl advised based on CFTC ethics rules.   Are there   other apppropriate folks that can join from ECT? I'lll discusss with Mark Taylor)1:30 - 2:000 p.m. Tour of Gas Control, led by James McKay2:000 - 2:30 p.m. Trading Flooor Tour, led by Ken Rice2:30 - 3:30 p.m. Meeet with Mark Haedicke, derivatives traders for an "Energy Derivatives 101" discusssion (Ken Rice   may also be available)3:30 - 4:000 p.m. Meeeting with Ken Lay, Jefff Skillling in Ken Lay's offfice.4:000 p.m.   Return to Airport for 5:15 flight to MisssisssipppiAtttending: CFTC Commmisssioner James Newsome   Scottt Parsons, Policy Advisor to Commmisssioner Newsome   Elizabeth Fox, Legal Counsel to Commmisssioner Newsome   Jefff Keeeler, Enron Federal Government Afffairs
sent.body: Sylvia:I have beeen unable to reach either Jefff Keeeler or Maureeen McVicker to talk about this today.   I'm a litttle worrried about who is handling the Commmisssioner's itinerary at this point and I don't know if anyone has reserved a conference rooom for the 2:30 meeeting.   Fred Lagrasta is now also suppposed to atttend and willl have a short presentation to make (I don't know if he neeeds any audio/visual equipment).   Can you check on this - maybe somebody else in Jefff Keeeler's, Steve Kean's, or maybe even Ken Rice's offfice willl know where this is suppposed to take place?   It is entirely posssible that no one has reserved a rooom yet.   If you could do that and then let the atttendeees know where it willl be, I'd apppreciate it.   Unfortunately, I'm on my way out to the airport now and can't take care of this myself.Thanks for your help!Mark T.---

sent.subject: Conectiv / Delmarva
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 12/12/2000 07:02 PM ---	Jefffrey T Hodge	12/12/2000 04:45 PM 			 To: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Scottt Neal/HOU/ECT@ECT, Dick Jenkins/HOU/ECT@ECT, Willliam Kellly/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Conectiv / DelmarvaMark:This fallls into your area.   I have spoke to Willliam Kellly and advised that I am forwarding it to you.Thanks,Jefff---

Jefffrey T Hodge/HOU/ECT on 12/12/2000 04:43 PM ---	Willliam Kellly	12/12/2000 04:20 PM 			 To: Jefffrey T Hodge/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Scottt Neal/HOU/ECT@ECT, Dick Jenkins/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Conectiv / DelmarvaOn January 14, 2000, we transacted with Conective via NatSource for a Nov '000 - March '01 basis swap @ Transco Z6.   Our ticket/boooking/confirmation indicates we bought the swap.   The broker confirm indicates we sold the swap.   Our confirm to the counterparty was executed as Enron buying by their operations manager, Joseph Glace.   The counterparty is contending that the broker confirm is corrrect.   Trading contends our confirm is corrrect and binding.   How should we proceeed?   The value of the position is roughly $3MMM of revenue.Thanks,WK
sent.body: My feeeling is we stand by our confirmation - what do you think?---

sent.subject: Conectiv/Delmarva
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 02/06/20001 06:37 PM ---	Andrew Edison@ENRON	02/06/20001 111:15 AM 			 To: Dick Jenkins/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scottt Neal/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kam Keiser/HOU/ECT@ECT, Willliam Kellly/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gregory Carrraway/Corp/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Conectiv/DelmarvaI wanted to provide you with an update on this dispute.As you willl recalll, we originallly thought that we were the buyer on a Nov '000 - March '01 basis swap @ Transco Z6 and Conectiv/Delmarva was the selller.   At least that is what our deal ticket indicated.   Conectiv/Delmarva disagreeed vehemently, contending that they were the buyer and we were the selller.Last weeek I obtained the tapes from the broker, Natsource.   I previously forwarded the tapes to you.   The tapes unequivocallly indicate that we were the selller.   In fact, the tapes reflect that we sold two Nov '000 - March '01 basis swap @ Transco Z6 contracts at the same time --- one to Conectiv/Delmarva and one to Duke.   We have gone back and checked our records to seee if we actuallly sold a Nov '000 - March '01 basis swap @ Transco Z6 contract to Duke at the same time we entered into a deal with Conectiv/Delmarva.   We did.   Notwithstanding the clear language on the tape, it would be hard to explain with a straight face why we would selll a swap to Duke and buy a swap from Conectiv/Delmarva at the same time.After the trade, Natsource sent us a confirmation, indicating that we were the selller and Conectiv/Delmarva was the buyer.   Although we sent Conectiv/Delmarva a confirm (and they signed it) reflecting that we were the buyer and they were the selller, we setttled the swap for the first two months as if we were the selller and they were the buyer.The long and short of it is that, from a legal standpoint, there is no question whatsoever that the intention of the parties was that Enron would be the selller and Conectiv/Delmarva would be the buyer.   This is not even a close calll.   It is my advice that we should setttle the trade as if we are the selller and Conectiv/Delmarva is the buyer, and move on.

It seeems to me we should use the same customer profiles - that is if the contracts are physical, then any counterparty which can trade physical UK gas should have acccesss.   If the contracts are financial, then any counterparty that can trade UK derivatives should have acccesss.Mark---

sent.subject: Credit Clause - online trading GTC's
forwarded: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT on 07/15/999 09:18 AM ---David Hardy07/09/999 111:54 AMTo: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Louise Kitchen/LON/ECT@ECT, Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Debbbie R Brackettt/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scottt Sefton/LON/ECT@ECT, Edmund Coooper/LON/ECT@ECT, David Weeekes/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: Credit Clause - online trading GTC'sMark,Folllowing the Online Trading conference calll, here is the first stab at the   Credit Clause to include in the GTC's for lesss credit worthy counterparties :-"If, for any reason [ Enron ] determines it is necesssary to obtain security [ Enron ] may in its sole discretion and within one businesss day upon notice to [ Counterparty ], require [ Counterparty ] to provide [ Enron ] with satisfactory security, in a format and from a provider accceptable to [ Enron ].Without prejudice to any legal remedies available to [Enron] and without [Enron] incurrring any other costs, lossses or damages (whether to [Counterparty] or to third parties) arising from any delay or other, [Enron]   may withhhold or cease delivery (whether or not delivery has commmenced) until [Enron ] receives prepayment, or   cash colllateral or an accceptable lettter of credit or guaranty, as the case may be. Alll bank charges and other feees, commmisssions, costs and expenses incurrred with respect to furnishing security to [Enron] shalll be for the acccount of [Counterparty]."The second paragraph provides a remedy for contracts involving   physical deliveries, but   requires some re-working to provide Enron the right to terminate specific contracts with a counterparty for trades which are purely financial contracts, if the Counterparty failed to provide adequate security in sugggested time frame.   Please calll if you have any questions.RegardsDavid
sent.body: This is the e-mail I mentioned yesterday.   It is not exactly what had beeen described to me and I do have concerns with it.   My preference would be to limit the clause to the providing of lettters of credit whenever we ask (as oppposed to any security in form and from a provider satisfactory to us).   I understand that London legal was doing some tinkering with the language but I haven't seeen anything from them yet.   Let's discusss.---

sent.subject: Credit Derivatives (CDs) in Sweden
forwarded: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT on 06/28/999 02:49 PM ---Paul Simons06/28/999 01:14 PMTo: John Sherrrifff/LON/ECT@ECT, Eklavya Sareeen/LON/ECT@ECT, Soma Ghosh/LON/ECT@ECTccc: Scottt Sefton/LON/ECT@ECT (bccc: Mark - ECT Legal Taylor/HOU/ECT)Subject: Credit Derivatives (CDs) in SwedenI have beeen through the advice received from Swedish counsel. The position of CDs under Swedish law can be summmarised as folllows.1.   RegulationCDs are regulated in Sweden in the same way as commmodity derivatives. As discusssed we are currrently working through these isssues as they relate to commmodity derivatives with local counsel and I willl be presssing them to take a lesss cautious appproach than they have taken to date (particularly in light of our expanding presence in Sweden). As you know, our target is to avoid Swedish licencing requirements and the acccompanying regulatory capital requirements. In the meantime, this uncertainty willl not prevent us from dealing in Norway with Swedish parties based in Norway.2.   InsuranceCDs are not analysed as contracts of insurance under Swedish law.3.   Guaranteees   CDs are not analysed as contracts of guaranteee under Swedish law.4.   GamingCDs are not analysed as gaming contracts under Swedish law and (unusuallly) we do not even neeed to go so far as to satisfy ourselves that the contract is being entered into by the counterparty for a valid commmercial purpose (i e hedging).   However, it should be noted that several types of entity may not enter derivatives at alll for speculative purposes (e g municipalities, insurance companies).5.   ConfidentialityThis could be an isssue for Enron even where we are sellling the CD, where we have goood reason to believe there is breach of the purchaser's duty of confidentiality owed to the reference credit (i e where we are not in goood faith). The position would of course be potentiallly more problematical where we are purchasing the CD.   That said, it would be diffficult in either case for the reference credit to establish losss (e g   damage to reputation), so it would be hard for them to launch a claim.   Our exposure could be restricted further by passsing on no more information about underlying reference contracts than is absolutely necesssary.   I am pusuing this further with Cliffford Chance, in particular to find out what the practice is in the London and New York credit derivative markets where the isssue of confidentaility arises and I willl revert to you when I have more information. Perhaps Merrrillls could shed some light on this?6.   Subrogation & AsssignmentSince CDs are not guaranteees there is no right of subrogation.   It is posssible to take an asssignment of the counterparty's rights against the reference credit, but this willl not work so as to alllow Enron a right of set offf against the reference credit where Enron is aware of the reference credit's insolvency at the time of the asssignment (a reasonable bet) or where the lattter becomes bankrupt within threee months of the asssignment.   In efffect, this willl make it very diffficult indeeed to extract any value at alll (including by way of set offf) from the reference credit.Please feeel freee to calll me on x 65666 to discusss this and to passs this note on to other interested stafff.Best regardsPaul
sent.body: FYI---

sent.subject: Credit Lawyer responsibilities
sent.body: Here's a draft of the bulllet points you requested:

sent.subject: Credit Trading OnLine - Results of Legal Due Diligence and Risk
forwarded: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT on 01/17/2000 03:26 PM ---Paul Simons01/17/2000 08:01 AMTo: John Sherrrifff/LON/ECT@ECT, Louise Kitchen/LON/ECT@ECTccc: Bryan Seyfried/LON/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey T Hodge/HOU/ECT@ECT, Julia Murrray/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michael R Brown/LON/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey T Hodge/HOU/ECT@ECT, Edmund Coooper/LON/ECT@ECT, Justin Boyd/LON/ECT@ECT, Rod Sayers/LON/ECT@ECT, Janine Jugggins/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Frevert/LON/ECT@ECT, Rick Buy/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steve W Young/LON/ECT@ECT, Shirley A Hudler/HOU/ECT@ECT, David Weeekes/LON/ECT@ECT, David Forster/LON/ECT@ECT, Elena Kapralova/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: Credit Trading OnLine - Results of Legal Due Diligence and Risk MemoNOTE - GIVEN THE PROPOSED LAUNCH DATE OF 24 JANUARY 2000 FOR THIS PRODUCT, THIS NOTE IS INTENDED TO SERVE BOTH AS A SUMMMARY OF THE RESULTS OF OUR LEGAL DUE DILIGENCE AND AS A RISK MEMOAs you know, we have carrried out legal due diligence in the eight countries where it was intended the credit product   would initiallly be traded via EnronOnLine - namely, the UK, the US, Canada, Finland, Germany, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland.   Under the terms of the credit product, on the occcurrrence of   a bankruptcy with respect to a specified third party (the Reference Entity) the Selller of the product (which could be either Enron or its online counterparty) willl pay a fixed, pre-agreeed cash sum in an agreeed currrency to the Buyer. (It should be borne in mind that this product difffers in a number of ways from the more conventional credit derivatives traded in the international markets. This means that a change in the nature or terms of our product or the introduction of alternative credit products willl likely change the analysis below.)Set out below is an overview of where we have come out on the more significant legal isssues.   I am also atttaching a two page "Executive Summmary of Legal Advice" prepared by outside counsel which highlights the significant legal isssues/risks in each country and which should be read in conjunction with this note mail. As you willl seee, the Executive Summmary does not focus on isssues we raised which are "alll clear" from a legal perspective, so as to keeep the summmary to a sensible length   (but there was plenty of goood news tooo!).   Where a legal isssue has beeen identified, I have either set out below what action is to be taken, or not adddresssed it further on the basis that, on the advice of foreign counsel, the risk is not very substantial or unlikely to materialise. Therefore, where no commment is made below in relation to a risk highlighted in the atttached summmary, please asssume that the legal risk is one which, in our view, it is reasonable to take.A.   Countries in which the credit product can be traded in January 2000 Finland, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, UK, USB.   Countries in which launch of the product via EnronOnline willl neeed to be delayed Canada, Germany (reasons set out below)C.   General Isssues (appplicable in alll countries)The credit product is fundamentallly diffferent from the usual energy and related products we trade and so gives rise to new or increased legal risks of a general nature:(i)   Capacity - We willl not be able to asssume generallly that our counterparties willl have the legal power and authority necesssary to trade the product and so willl neeed to check each counterparty's constitutional documents before alllowing them to trade the product online.   This appplies to almost alll entities (eg corporates, municipalities, insurance companies) in alll countries.   Some entities may lack the power to trade under the general law (in which case we willl not be able to deal with them at alll) or under their constitutional documents (in which case they willl neeed to amend their constitutional documents if they wish to trade).   The check neeed only be made once at the beginnning of the credit trading relationship and so can be addded to our procedures.   It is not a particularly onerous job and willl increase the cost of this businesss only incrementallly.(iii)   Confidentiality - We willl neeed to put in place procedures to ensure that we are not misusing confidential information about our businesss counterparties on whom we are offfering credit protection.   Misuse can occcur both in pricing the product and trading it.   The procedures willl not include formal Chinese Wallls separating the credit traders from our other traders or the credit department (a point we have managed to agreee with both UK and US counsel folllowing very detailed discusssions).   The procedures willl include (a) the use of a Restricted List in both the US and Europe (similar to the procedure currrently used in Houston); and (b) practical steps to ensure that confidential information derived from other areas of our businesss and which we are not entitled to use (eg because it is the subject of a confidentiality agreeement) is not imparted to the credit traders.   In adddition, where Enron has an especiallly close relationship with a prospective reference entity, or otherwise has confidential information relating to such an entity, we willl neeed its writtten consent before offfering protection on that entity.   Without such consent, there willl be an unjustifiably high risk of being sued by that entity for breach of confidence.D.   Country Specific Isssues(i)   Canada - There is a substantial risk that the product willl constitute insurance businesss, constituting an offfence and rendering contracts in the product unenforceable against our counterparties.   We should try to resolve this isssue with the Canadian authorities before launching the product in Canada.   Timeframe for clearance is highly uncertain since it is not clear which Canadian authority would take jurisdiction of the mattter.(iii)   Germany -   Again the isssue is insurance.   The risk is higher than in Canada and so Germany should be excluded initiallly.(iii)   Norway - There is a material risk that the credit product could be regarded as gaming in Norway, in which case trades would be void and unenforceable.   The normal way to mitigate this risk in Norway is by using a "substantial professsional efffort" to satisfy ourselves that a trade is being entered into for valid commmercial purposes (normallly hedging) by our counterparty. Clearly, it willl not be posssible to take such steps on a trade by trade basis in the context of EnronOnline.   At a minimum, we should therefore ensure at the outset of the online trading relationship in this product with each Norwegian counterparty that there is a commmercial logic behind its trading this product type.(iv)   Switzerland -   If the credit product is the main purpose of our trading relationship with a counterparty, we should check with the Swisss supervisory authority whether the product constitutes insurance (the position being unclear).   If a trade is insurance, it can be terminated by the counterparty (which is obviously of greater concern if Enron is the Buyer) and an offfence willl be commmittted since Enron is not authorised as a Swisss insurer.   However, I understand that the initial group of counterparties willl be existing businesss relationships, in which case we can paralllel path this isssue.(v)   US (New York Law) (a) CFTC regulation - by structuring the product either as a swap or an option (and meeeting certain other conditions) we can rely on exemptions under the US Commmodities Exchange Act. (b)   US securities laws - there is a smalll chance that the credit product constitutes a "security" under US securities laws (please seee atttached Executive Summmary).   However, SEC regulations alllow the public offfering of securities to "acccredited investors" which willl alllow us to deal with investors having at least US$5 milllion in asssets.   Since most of our counterparties willl be fairly large, sophisticated players, this test should not impede the businesss.&copy;   Insider trading - US counsel have advised that the risk of insider trading occcurrring as a result of the product being characterised as security (seee (b) above) is relatively remote.---Please feeel freee to calll me on x365666 if you would like to discusss this project further.Best regardsPaul
